greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: number of topologically distinct sets of n circles with one pair intersecting, by number of factors.
link: R. J. Mathar, Topologically Distinct Sets of Non-intersecting Circles in the Plane, arXiv:1603.00077 [math.CO], 2016.
mathematica: A027852[n_] := Module[{dh = 0, np}, For[np = 0, np <= n, np++, dh = a81[np]*a81[n - np] + dh]; If[EvenQ[n], dh = a81[n/2] + dh]; dh/2];
t[n_] := t[n] = Module[{d, j}, If[n == 1, 1, Sum[Sum[d*t[d], {d, Divisors[j]}]*t[n - j], {j, 1, n - 1}]/(n - 1)]];
b[n_, i_, p_] := b[n, i, p] = If[p > n, 0, If[n == 0, 1, If[Min[i, p] < 1, 0, Sum[b[n - i*j, i - 1, p - j]*Binomial[t[i] + j - 1, j], {j, 0, Min[n/i, p]}]]]]; A033185[n_, k_] := b[n, n, k];
Table[A280787[n, f], {n, 2, 11}, {f, 1, n - 1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 23 2017, after _R. J. Mathar_ and _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jan 20 2017
